habitat_description:
The Chihuahuan hook-nosed snake occurs from southeastern Arizona, New Mexico, and western Texas south into San Luis Potosi and Zacatecas, Mexico at an elevational range of 305 to 2100 meters (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Hardy 1976; Stebbins 2003).

The habitat of this semifossorial snake is constituted by desert, grassland, herbaceous areas, shrubland, savanna, chaparral, and conifer, hardwood and mixed woodland. This species burrows in loose soils, but also in rocky soil types with reduced sand and gravel composition. It also uses fallen logs, debris, and leaf litter as burrowing and cover sites (Ernst and Ernst 2003). The habitat of this snake includes grassy foothills, lower desert communities, and in higher elevations characterized by persimmon-shin oak, oak-juniper savanna and woodland, and pinyon-juniper woodland (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Stebbins 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000). In the northernmost localities of its range, this species occupies flat and rolling prairie grassland with limestone and gypsum outcroppings (Ferguson 1965).

SW - Uses rocks, soil, grasses, leaf litter, and logs as cover. Also associated with communities of persimmon-shin oak, oak-juniper savanna and woodland, and pinyon-juniper woodland.
